title: RL33929
content: Each year, Congress funds the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) to renew over 2.1 million Section 8 vouchers, which are rental subsidies for low-income families in the private market. These vouchers help cover the gap between rent and the tenant's contribution (30% of adjusted income). The program is federally funded and governed by federal rules but administered locally by public housing authorities (PHAs). The Section 8 voucher program provides rental subsidies for low-income families, covering the gap between rent and the tenant's contribution. The cost of a voucher to a Public Housing Authority (PHA) is based on the difference between actual rent and the maximum subsidy level, as well as 30% of the tenant's income. Changes in tenant incomes, rents, and payment standards impact this cost. Congress and HUD have made changes to voucher renewal funding distribution to PHAs in recent years. In recent years, Congress has made changes to the way voucher renewal funding is distributed to local Public Housing Authorities (PHAs), leading to funding uncertainty and pressure for permanent funding reform. This report discusses the changes enacted since FY2003 and their effects on PHAs administering the voucher program. Since FY2003, PHAs administering the voucher program were funded based on their average annual per-voucher cost from the previous year, adjusted by an inflation factor. They also received a reserve equal to one month of voucher funding. Despite full funding, few PHAs leased 100% of their authorized vouchers, leading to low utilization rates, a concern for Congress. In FY2000 and FY2001, national voucher utilization rates were just over 91%, below the expected 95%. PHAs had low budget utilization due to not using all vouchers, resulting in excess funds in their budgets. HUD would reconcile budgets at year-end and recapture excess funds from PHAs' reserves. HUD used a formula based on previous year's costs and inflation to request funding from Congress for Section 8 vouchers. PHAs could use excess funds for new vouchers through maximized leasing.
